title: Why do some people have outies and some have innies?
text:
Why do some people have outies and some have innies?

(Rui Santos/123RF)

Why do I have a hole in the middle of my tummy? Is it just there to collect lint and fluff or is there a greater purpose for that button on my belly? And why does mine poke in while my friends' pokes out?

Well hold onto your belly buttons because we’re going to learn everything there is to know about them!

Innie or outie?

An innie belly button and an outie belly button. (innie: Wikimedia/G.dallorto; outie: Photo credit: Kid Gibson on VisualHunt / CC BY-NC-SA)

Look down at your tummy.

You might notice that your belly button pokes out and makes a little bump on your tummy (an outie).

Or it's a dark hole that seems to go on forever into your belly (an innie). But is it just there for decoration?

Why do I even have a belly button?

Why am I stuck with this hole in my stomach? Good question!

Your belly button is actually there for a very important reason. It goes all the way back to before you were even born!

When a baby is growing inside a mother’s womb, they are connected to their mom by a soft, bendy rope called the umbilical cord.

That cord is how the baby eats, breathes and gets rid of waste to help them develop.

When the baby is born, they can drink milk, breathe air and get rid of their waste in a diaper. So they don’t need the cord anymore!

A doctor cuts the cord, so the baby is no longer connected to their mom. They tie or clamp the cord close to the baby’s tummy.

Since there are no nutrients going to the cord anymore, after a few weeks it dries up and falls off, leaving a belly button in its place!

So I can untie my belly button?

(Kwanchai Chai-udom/123RF)

No! The belly button is kind of like a scar. You can't reopen your belly button.

Depending on how the scar tissue forms will decide whether you have an innie or an outie!

Innies are much more common. Only about 10 per cent of people have an outie! But 100 per cent of people have a belly button!

Does my belly button do anything?

Does it help me do more sit-ups? Can I breathe more with it? Can you untie it and see inside my tummy? All great guesses, but no.

Now that you're older, the most your belly button does is collect bacteria.

Microorganisms (bacteria so small you can’t see them) live all over your body. But a popular hangout spot for them is in your belly button.

Scientists are finding new species of microorganisms in belly buttons all the time.

But don’t stress! The bacteria in your belly button isn’t all bad.

Just remember to wash your belly button to keep it sparkly clean.
